flow.descriptionCdata:
7819a92e-0a9a-43ed-94ee-af082a05b751.078e065b-a271-4977-996e-7050b076b0bc.callout=This workflow will provision a Windows EC2 instance and upon completion send an email to the requestor with the connection user and password 7819a92e-0a9a-43ed-94ee-af082a05b751.3063eed1-1206-4087-8874-b983c1c5cb0f.callout=3 Minute wait for auto-generated password to complete 7819a92e-0a9a-43ed-94ee-af082a05b751.4cb14e4f-a326-46a8-8353-97b770a5fe88.description=This flow launches an instance and attaches to it one or more volumes, depending on your needs. Inputs\: accessKeyId - The ID of the secret access key associated with your Amazon AWS or IAM account. accessKey - The secret access key associated with your Amazon AWS or IAM account. proxyHost - The proxy server used to connect to Amazon. proxyPort - The proxy server port. You must either specify values for both and inputs or leave them both empty. proxyUsername - The proxy server user name. proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the input value. serviceEndpoint - The endpoint to which requests are sent. To select a specific region, you either mention the endpoint corresponding to that region or provide a value to region input. In case both serviceEndpoint and region are specified, the serviceEndpoint will be used and region will be ignored. Default value\: ec2.amazonaws.com Examples\: ec2.us-east-1.amazonaws.com, ec2.us-west-2.amazonaws.com, ec2.us-west-1.amazonaws.com, ec2.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com, ec2.ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com, ec2.ap-northeast-1.amazonaws.com, ec2.sa-east-1.amazonaws.com region - The region where to deploy the instance. To select a specific region, you either mention the endpoint corresponding to that region or provide a value to region input. In case both serviceEndpoint and region are specified, the serviceEndpoint will be used and region will be ignored. Examples\: us-east-1, us-east-2, us-west-1, us-west-2, ca-central-1, eu-west-1, eu-central-1, eu-west-2, ap-northeast-1, ap-northeast-2, ap-southeast-1, ap-southeast-2, ap-south-1, sa-east-1 amiId - The ID of the image (AMI) which you want to use in order to create your instance. instanceType - The type of the instance. Default value\: m1.small keyName - The name used by the key pair to access your instance. Launching public images without a key pair ID leaves them inaccessible. subnetId - The ID of the subnet within which to launch the instances for Amazon VPC. privateIpAddress - The IP address from the VPC subnet that is assigned to the instance. If you specify an IP address, you can launch a single instance. Default value\: an IP address selected by Amazon VPC from the subnet securityGroupId - The IDs of the security groups your instances will be part of. kernelId - The ID of the operating system kernel used for instance launching. availabilityZone - Specifies the placement constraints (availability zones) for launching instances. Amazon automatically selects an availability zone by default. ramdiskId - The ID of the RAM disk with which to launch the instance. securityGroups - The name of the security group or groups your instances will be part of. If empty, the default group is used. placementGroup - The name of the placement group your instances will be part of. clientToken - A unique identifier (case-sensitive string of up to 64 ASCII characters) you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. If the operation timeouts or connection errors occur, you can rerun the operation to make sure you haven't launched more instances than you intended. If you repeat the request with the same client token, the same response is returned each time. You can use the same client token for the same request across different regions. The client token is valid for at least 24 hours after instance termination. Do not reuse a client token for a later call. placementTenacy - The tenancy of the instance you want to launch. An instance with a tenancy of dedicated runs on single-tenant hardware and can only be launched into a VPC. networkInterfaceId - An existing interface ID to be attached to the instance. userData - The Base64-encoded MIME user data for the instances. instanceName - This will be the preffix of the instance name. A 5 digits suffix is added to this name in order to avoid name duplication. This name will be overwritten if another name will be provided in the list of tags. tagKeyList - The keys of the tags that you want to add to your instance. The length of this list must be equal to the length of the list contained by the tagValueList input. Use the tag key Name in this list if you want to set a specific instance name and it will remain unchanged, will not receive the suffix as in case of the instanceName input. tagValueList - the values for th e keys provided in the tagKeyList. The lengths of these two list must be the same, and the order of the tag values has to correspond the order of the tag keys. delimiter - The delimiter used to separate the elements of the tagKeyList and tagValueList inputs. volumeSizeList - A list containing the sizes of the volumes, in GBs, to be created and attached to the instance. Format\: ,, Valid values for sizes\: from 1 to 1024 Examples\: 8,16,32 volumeType - The type of the volumes. Valid values\: gp2 (for General Purpose (SSD) volumes), io1 (for Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes) and standard (for Magnetic volumes) Default value\: standard iops - The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) to provision for the volumes. Only valid for Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes. Valid values\: from 100 to 4,000 encrypted - Specifies whether the volumes should be encrypted. Valid values\: true and false Default value\: false requestCount - The maximum number of requests to send to Amazon for checking that the instnace has the expected status. If the instance status is not as expected after executing the maximum number of requests, the flow fails. Format\: a positive integer Default value\: 60 requestInterval - The number of seconds to wait until a new request is sent to Amazon. Format\: a positive integer Default Value\: 5 rollbackType - Specifies whether the rollback should be done full or not at all. Valid Values\: FULL_ROLLBACK, NO_ROLLBACK Default Value\: FULL_ROLLBACK Results\: returnResult - This will contain the response message. In case of an error this output will contain the error message. returnCode - It contains the value 0 if the flow successfully completed and the value -1 if an error occurred. instanceId - The ID of the newly created instance. ipAddress - The IP address of the instance. hostname - The hostname of the instance. fqdn - The FQDN of the instance. osType - The type of platform the deployed instance is. macAddress - The MAC address of the network interface. availabilityZone - The availability zone of the instance. volumeIdList - The list containing the IDs of the volumes newly created and attached to the instance. Responses\: success - The flow has run as the description states. failure - An exception occured during the flow execution. Notes\: 1. Check all the service endpoints available for the specified product at\: http\://docs.amazonwebservices.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html\#ec2_region 2. As with all Amazon EC2 operations, the results might not appear immediately. 3. Some Availability Zones in us-east-1, us-west-1, or ap-northeast-1 do not support SSD volumes such as Provisioned IOPS (SSD) and General Purpose (SSD). 4. Encrypted volumes may only be attached to selected instance types. For more information, see http\://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/EBSEncryption.html 5. You must specify a value for the size or for the snapshot id. They can't be both null in the same call. 6. You may specify a value either for size or snapshotId, but not for both in the same call. 7. You must not specify a value for the iops field if the volume type is General Purpose (SSD) or Provisioned IOPS (SSD). 7819a92e-0a9a-43ed-94ee-af082a05b751.52fdf908-086a-4863-b60b-61c0d66e575c.description=
This flow sends, stores or displays a notification message according to your notification type selection. You can use this flow to select how to be notified about the outcome of other flows. 

Inputs\:
    notifyData -  The content of the notification message.
    notifyMethod - The notification type. This value is not case sensitive.
Valid values\: Write to File, Email, Display or None
    subject - A summary of the notification content. 
    destination - The destination of the notification. You must specify a value for this input if "notifyMethod" is set to ‘Email’ or ‘Write to File’.
Valid values\: An email address or a file name
    notificationServer - The email server used to send the notification email message. If "notifyMethod" is set to ‘Email’, you must specify a value for this input.
    from - The email address of the sender of the notification email message.  If "notifyMethod" is set to ‘Email’, you must specify a value for this input.
    serverPort - The notification service’s server port. This field’s value is used when the "notifyMethod" is ‘Email’, but it is optional.
Default value\: 25
    htmlEmail - The value should be true if the email is in rich text/HTML format. The value should be false to send the email in plain text format.
Default value\: true

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Note\:
    To schedule a flow that uses this flow, you need to supply all the required fields for the used notification method. For example, if "notifyMethod" is set to ‘File’, the "destination" input must also be specified.

Examples\:
    This is a valid input example for storing a notification message to a file\:
      notifyData\: notificationContent
      notifyMethod\: Write to File
      subject\: notificationSubject
      destination\: C\:\Program File\notification.txt
7819a92e-0a9a-43ed-94ee-af082a05b751.59b8486b-e2e8-4fe7-aeed-689399466855.description=
This operation waits for the number of seconds specified in the "seconds" input.

Inputs\:
    seconds - The number of seconds to wait.

Results\:
    resultString – This is the primary output. It contains the "completed sleep" message if the operation completed successfully and an error message otherwise. 

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.
7819a92e-0a9a-43ed-94ee-af082a05b751.f7308706-98a7-47c8-9aa3-c2ef712b5066.description=
This operation uses WMI to attempt to create a remote process on target machine and run the command. 

Inputs\:
    host - Hostname or ip address of the target machine.
    command - The command you want to execute. Special characters\: '<', '>', '(', ')', '&' need to be escaped using the caret ('^') character.  The only exception to this rule is when the '>' character is used to redirect output.
    currentDirectory - The directory from which the command will be executed.
    user - Username to use for remote WMI impersonation and thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank).
    password - Password of the user.
    outputPath - Network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default the path will have to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    characterSet - The character encoding used to write the batch file that will be remotely executed by the operation. Unicode character encodings may not be supported for this input (utf-8, utf-16, etc.).  Support for unicode encodings depends on target system capabilities.  By default this encoding will also be used to read the command output that is redirected to temporary files.  If the command output is expected to be of different encoding, specify the different encoding in the "outputCharacterSet" input.  
Default value\: The encoding of the operating system where is RAS installed.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis
    outputCharacterSet - The character encoding used to read the command output that was redirected to temporary files.  Only need to specify this input if the output of the command is known to be of a different character encoding.  As an example\: the "wmic" command returns utf-16 encoded output.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis, utf-8, utf-16
    timeout - The number of seconds before assuming the remote process is no longer functional. After the timeout has expired the remote process and all child processes will be terminated.
Default value\: 600
    useDelegation - This input must be added by the user in order to be used. If set to "true" the operation will use the "Delegate" impersonation level and the "Kerberos" authentication protocol. If "false", empty or missing the operation will use "Impersonate" for the impersonation level and the default authentication protocol (which is NTLM).
Values\: true, false
Default\: false
    debugPath - This input must be added by the user in order to be used. If set to "true", an additional result field named "commandPassed" is returned and it contains the command that executes the script. For more information on the purpose of this input, see the "Notes" section.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It is the value from WMI for starting the process (not the exit value of the process).
    processID - The process id of the remote process.
    processReturnCode - The return code of the remote process.
    stdOut - Standard output from the remote process.
    stdErr - Standard error from the remote process.

Responses\:
    success - Remote process successfully launched and has completed executing.
    failure - Unable to start remote process.

Notes\: 
1. Internally this operation creates a temporary batch file with the following content\:

cmd /c " [command] 2> err.tmp 1> out.tmp "
echo %ERRORLEVEL% > ret.tmp

After the script is executed, the operation will read the files\: err.tmp (standard error), out.tmp (standard output) and ret.tmp (return code). Finally the operation deletes all the temporary files.
The command that executes the script can be accesed by adding a new input\: debugPath with the value\: "true"

2. List of possible encoding names (Support for the encoding may depend on the version or language of the RAS OS)\:
Encoding Name\:	Description\:
IBM437		OEM United States
DOS-720		Arabic (DOS)
ibm737		Greek (DOS)
ibm775		Baltic (DOS)
ibm850		Western European (DOS)
ibm852		Central European (DOS)
IBM855		OEM Cyrillic
ibm857		Turkish (DOS)
IBM00858		OEM Multilingual Latin I
IBM860		Portuguese (DOS)
ibm861		Icelandic (DOS)
DOS-862		Hebrew (DOS)
IBM863		French Canadian (DOS)
IBM864		Arabic (864)
IBM865		Nordic (DOS)
cp866		Cyrillic (DOS)
ibm869		Greek, Modern (DOS)
shift_jis		Japanese (Shift-JIS)
gb2312		Chinese Simplified (GB2312)
ks_c_5601-1987	Korean
big5		Chinese Traditional (Big5)
utf-16		Unicode
unicodeFFFE		Unicode (Big-Endian)
utf-7		Unicode (UTF-7)
utf-8		Unicode (UTF-8)
utf-32		Unicode (UTF-32)
utf-32BE		Unicode (UTF-32 Big-Endian)
Johab		Korean (Johab)
us-ascii		US-ASCII
koi8-r		Cyrillic (KOI8-R)
euc-jp		Japanese (EUC)
EUC-CN		Chinese Simplified (EUC)
euc-kr		Korean (EUC)
hz-gb-2312		Chinese Simplified (HZ)
GB18030		Chinese Simplified (GB18030)
flow.name: Provision EC2 Server

staticBinding.value:
A new Amazon EC2 Instance has been successfully created

Here is your new Host :  ${hostname}

IP Address : ${ipAddress}

MAC Address : ${macAddress}

 

You can log in to your new EC2 instance with the following access information :

Login Information :

Hostname : ${fqdn}

User ID : Administrator

Password : ${password} 

 


                                                                 Powered By
